title: Luxury: social psychological approaches for professionals  (2023-2024)
description:
####Learning objectives

The main objective of the course Luxury: social psychological approaches for professionals is to make students familiar with a social psychological perspective on the interactions in the world of luxury.
 
The course addresses the social psychological interactions and processes that underlie the world of luxury, as well as professional contexts in luxury businesses such as hotels, resorts, restaurants, the fashion world, make-up universes, etc. 

First, the course provides students with the social psychological keys to understand and contextualise the ways in which people think, feel, and behave in relation to luxury. 
 
Secondly, the course considers the contemporary stakes in the luxury world - for example, environmental concerns, as well as interactional stakes between luxury professionals and clients. 
 
Thirdly, the course equips students with the knowledge and tools to better understand the functioning of small groups, which are often created in luxury businesses: group affiliation and membership in work teams, leadership and its relation to group performance and group climate, norm formation, conformity, obedience, social influence, and social change, etc.
 
In addition, the course contributes to the development of students’ soft skills, such as active listening, leadership, conflict management, group work, cross-cultural interactional skills.

####Details of the learning scenario

A quiz is to complete for each topic.

Workload: 54 hours 

Final Assessment: Case study : a social psychological analysis (options : luxury fashion, luxury make-up, or luxury tourism)

#### Schedule/Timetable of the learning offer

Starts: **04/03/2024**

Ends: **13/05/2024**

title: The Fall of an Empire or the Rise of Europe? (Spring 2024)
description:
#### Learning objectives

In the traditional historiographical narrative, the arrival of the “barbarians” corresponds to the end of the greatest civilization of the antique Mediterranean: the Roman Empire. But was the situation so simple? Who were these “barbarians”? And did the Empire really collapse or was it rather transformed? The goal of this course is to focus on the artistic, visual, material, and performative cultures that coexisted in this extraordinary moment of history. To reach this objective, we will firstly focus on the prejudices constructed from the Renaissance to our days about what was commonly considered as the “Dark Ages”. Secondly, we will be investigating the role of medias in the transformations of visual history: from sculptures to “bidimensional” images, from roll to codex, from the illusive image to the iconic one. Third, we will analyze the role played by the meeting of cultures – constitutive for the investigated period – in the birth of the “Middle Ages”.

This course is taught by the Department of Art History at Masaryk University. 

At the end of the course participants will:
- be able to orientate himself in the visual and material cultures of the Late Antique to Early Medieval world;
- understand the tools and the importance of visual culture within social and historical phenomena;
- fall in love with art history!

#### Details of the learning scenario

This learning offer is **asynchronous**, which means that this is an e-learning course (e-learning materials + final essay).

Please consider a workload per the whole course of 125 hours (25 hours/1 ECTS).

title: German A1 at Zessko (Spring 2024): Weekly Video Meetings (Zoom) + Moodle-based learning
description:
#### Learning objectives

The course is aimed at learners who would like to begin studying German or go further after having taken a very few initial steps, – be it informal out-of-classroom learning, more formal in an A1.1 course, or self-directed online learning with Zessko’s “German A1 Starter” (https://courses.educalliance.eu/course/165) on the EDUC Moodle. 
Built on an action-orientated approach and a fully Moodle-based online learning material, the course addresses reception, production, interaction and mediation in terms of language activities in connection with language strategies in various but typical areas of communication related to academic life in Potsdam. Consequently, it does neither claim to “cover” the whole level A1 according to the CEFR nor to provide A1 exam training. Instead, it is to empower successful participants to take their first steps in a German speaking surrounding and – equally important – to manage their further language acquisition.

Upon successfully engaging in this course, learners:
- can recognise concrete information (e.g., places and times) on familiar topics encountered in everyday life, provided it is delivered slowly and clearly.
- can understand some expressions when people are discussing them: personal and academic life, hobbies or surroundings, provided the delivery is slow and clear.
- can understand instructions addressed carefully and slowly to them and follow short, simple directions.
- can understand very short, simple texts a single phrase at a time, picking up familiar names, words and basic phrases.
- can guess the probable meaning of an unknown word/sign that is similar to one in the language they normally use.
- can produce simple, mainly isolated phrases about people, time and places.
- can ask and answer simple questions, initiate and respond to simple statements in areas of immediate need or on very familiar topics.
- can make an introduction and use basic greeting and leave-taking expressions.
- can ask for food and drink using basic expressions.
- can handle numbers, quantities, cost and time (can-do statements according to the CEFR).

#### Details of the learning scenario

Mode: Regular video meetings via Zoom (language learning discussions, collaborative task-based learning) connected with asynchronous individual learning through Moodle (learning videos, exercises and quizzes, assignments).

**Workload: 180 h (*equivalent to 6 ECTS)**

End: 19/07/2024

**presumably Thursdays: weekly, 16:00 - 19:30 h (to be confirmed)**

Certificate of attendance, Zessko's A1 certificate upon passing the A1 exam, digital documents will be made available via Moodle.

title: Memorable Speaking: Making an Impact (English Oral Proficiency II) - Spring 2024
description:
#### Learning objectives

What makes a speech memorable? In this collaborative online international learning (COIL) project between the University of Potsdam and Beit Berl College (Israel), students listen to and learn from noted speakers in the fields of business, politics, literature, and education. In turn, students share their ideas on these topics by making memorable speeches of their own. We welcome students from the EDUC alliance to participate in some of the sessions (**for no ECTS points**) or for all of the sessions (for an EDUC certificate certifying the workload).
Please see "More Info" for the course time, expected outcomes, and requirements.

In this course students should master oral communication of an informative, explanatory, and persuasive nature through presenting. Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able

- to understand and identify the principles of various presentation formats
- to structure and present academic and professional presentations effectively
- to develop a central argument and to support it with compelling subpoints
- to formulate coherent ideas and opinions and express them precisely and succinctly
- to use appropriate transitions and signposting language to help the audience navigate a presentation
- to integrate and correctly reference credible sources as evidence for their argumentation
- to strengthen their verbal delivery using appropriate pronunciation features (e.g., chunking, emphatic stress, etc.)
  and non-verbal language for advanced communicative competence
- to feel confident in posing and responding to questions during a presentation

Students are required to participate in weekly class discussions. Independent study is an integral component of the course. Students are strongly encouraged to attend the English Language Café. (Your instructor will provide you with information; see also the departmental website.)

title: Writing Across Cultures (English Academic Writing II) - Spring 2024
description:
#### Learning objectives

Taking the UNESCO working paper "Intercultural Competence: Conceptual and Operational Framework" (Leeds-Hurwitzand Stenou, 2013) as a springboard, we investigate the meaning and relevance of intercultural competence in today's world. Students then research and write about a topic of their choosing that is related to intercultural competence. Exercises that develop students' peer review skills will help them to identify and correct errors in their peers' and in their own writing. We view writing squarely as a process and consequently do portfolio work over the course of the semester. The semester culminates in a short presentation of the students' essays.
We welcome students in the EDUC alliance to participate in some of the sessions (**for no ECTS points**) or for all of the sessions (for an EDUC certificate certifying the workload). Passive participants will be removed from the Moodle course.

This two-hour writing course centers on essay writing and the argumentative essay in particular. Upon completion of this course, students will be able
- to express themselves using nuanced language (improved accuracy and appropriacy of writing)
- to produce cohesive and coherent academic writing (improved complexity and effectiveness of writing)
- to identify and produce various types of academic texts
- to evaluate their own and others' texts (peer review)
- to assess and cite (MLA) appropriate sources properly

description:
These asynchronous courses are designed for EDUC students utilizing self-guided activities to prepare them for language exams in English, German, Hungarian and Czech – four of the languages represented in the EDUC network of universities. Students enrolling in the course will have opportunities to practice developing their receptive (reading and listen) and productive (writing and speaking) skills in these four languages, working through typical tasks found on language exams. These courses are built around the European Consortium of Languages (ECL), which is the University of Pecs’ foreign language exam system offering ECUC students and others across the EU and aboard language exam certificates in more than ten languages.

This online language assessment preparation course in Moodle will be structured around six learning modules for the target language and CEFR level: 1.) Introduction to the ECL Language Examination System at the University of Pecs, 2.) Reading section of assessment, 3.) Writing section of assessment, 4.) Listening section of assessment, 5.) Speaking section of assessment, and 6.) Online Practice Exam. In Moodle, participants will work through a series of pre-recorded screen casts of Google Slides and Prezi presentations to learn more about the content they can expect to encounter on the ECL language exam. They will also have access to PDF files, sample language assessments, and additional online resources to assist in preparation. All modules will include asynchronous resources for EDUC staff and students to work through the productive and receptive skills independently and at their own pace. However, the modules will include the following recommend time (Total Time: 6 weeks/22 hours) to spend on each language learning task in order to successfully prepare for a language assessment in the selected EDUC language. 

Teacher: Peter Sabath (UPE/PTE) https://inyk.pte.hu/munkatarsaink/

title: Refugee Integration? Critical reflections on history and the present 2024
description:
Section 1: Learning objectives

This intensive blended course delves into the global history of processes of refuge-seeking: it explores the many challenges that refugees and migrants face and the opportunities they create in receiving countries. It engages the manifold ways in which citizens have responded to migrants and refugees over time – from the Huguenots’ arrival in Brandenburg-Prussia in 1685 to the present – and in various places, including France, Australia, Uganda, Ethiopia, and Germany. The course also examines the responses and visions of migrants and refugees themselves.

The course brings together 30 students from six European universities through the European Digital UniverCity alliance (EDUC), for ten weeks of online learning (starting on April 17, 2022) followed by a week together in Potsdam June 24-29, 2024. In Potsdam students will meet with local decision-makers, civil society and church representatives, and migrants and refugees to learn first-hand about practices and issues relating to migration and integration.

To prepare for this, students will be introduced to theories around integration and will then engage with historic and contemporary case studies that highlight particular issues such as culture, religion, racism, education, and labour in relation to assimilationism and multiculturalism.

Overall, the aim of this course is to provide students with the theoretical and conceptual language to make sense of historical processes of refuge-seeking and integration as well as enabling a lively exchange between student perspectives and practitioners’ insights on processes of integration in the city of Potsdam.

At the end of the course participants will:
- develop an understanding of integration / multiculturalism / assimilation
- develop an understanding of historic roots of present-day integration challenges
- realize the global scale of integration measures
- reflect on interconnections between refugee and migration integration
- develop critical reading and reflection skills
-develop analysis of primary and secondary sources skills
- develop teamwork skills
-develop oral and written presentation skills
- develop intercultural skills
-develop transfer skills from historic case studies to present circumstances

Section 2: Details of the learning scenario

This learning offer is a “blended” one, which means that it is divided in two phases: an Online Program from April 19th to June 14th, 2022 consisting of one lesson every Tuesday from 16:00 to 18:00 h. And an On-site program from 24th to 29th of June, 2024.
Location: Online | University of Potsdam, Campus Neues Palais. 

Please consider a work-load:
- Online: 8 hours per week
- Onsite: 40 hours per week

The minimum technical requirements you need to participate are: a 5 Mbps Internet connexion and a Zoom account

title: My Culture and Yours: A Workshop Exploring Our Thinking, Languages, and Identity
description:
#### Learning objectives

”My Culture and Yours: A Workshop Exploring Our Thinking, Languages, and Identity” is a pilot project hosted by the language centers of the University of Potsdam and Tel Aviv University—respectively the Center for Language and Key Competences (Zessko) and Center for Language Excellence (CLE)—to create a COIL version of a language café. Extending the invitation to partake in the workshop to the language centers and students of the EDUC partner universities of the University of Potsdam, Zessko and CLE offer a three-session COIL in which students will get the chance to explore their own definition of culture, reflect on their own language and cultural background, practice communicating in English, and become acquainted with the new cultures and stories from their fellow participants. These themes will be mediated in story-telling and predominantly oral activities. In this virtual learning setting, students enhance their language proficiency in English as well as their intercultural communicative competence and are asked 1) to  embrace the opportunities that come with experiencing cultural diversity and 2) to then answer the overarching core question of this workshop about one’s own cultural identity; 3) to respect individual difference and shared global values, and 4) to ultimately rise to the EDUC’s mission statement of creating an inclusive and diverse digital space for intercultural exchange and discourse.

#### Details of the learning scenario

This learning offer is **virtual**, and **synchronous**.

Please consider a total work-load of: 4.5 hours (participation EDUC Certificate)

title: Cross-Cultural Communication
description:
#### Learning objectives

Using English as a Lingua Franca (in the case of this course British English is used) as the language of instruction, this course aims to explore perceptions and cultures through the lens of intercultural communication in the context of Europe. Through reflection and study, you will learn how to better identify communication breakdowns and develop new strategies to overcome them in international contexts. This means that this course does not focus on language learning. In this approach, language learning happens naturally as you progress through the course content regarding Cross-Cultural Communication. 

At the end of the course, you will:
- improve your ability to communicate with partners and peers from different cultures as well as your competence in the target language and increase your confidence.
- improve your soft skills (presentation and public speaking) in the target language. 
- have an opportunity to develop and foster international relationships with other EDUC partners.

#### Details of the learning scenario

This learning offer is asynchronous. To succeed in this online component, you need the following:
- B1 level in English
- To participate in the reflective activities
- To utilize online language resources (that you have found helpful in your experiences and / or the ones provided to you in the Introductory Manuel)
- Time
- Understand that this is an INDIVIDUAL study course and will not result in an official certification of language level

Please consider a work-load of: 30 hours

The minimum technical requirements you need to participate are: e.g.: good Internet connection and your university account to log in to [EDUC Moodle](https://learning.educalliance.eu/)

Starting: 15/05/2024
End: 15/11/2026

Evaluation period: from 16/11/2024 to 31/12/2024

title: Financing Research
description:
The lecture summarizes the principles of financing research in the academic sector. The lecturer introduces the participants to the most significant national and international programmes for financing research and give them orientation in appropriate financing mix at specific career stages.  The lecture then presents standard principles used in the evaluation of funding applications, basic evaluation criteria, and tips on what style of writing to use to impress the evaluators.

#### Target group

This training activity is intended primarily for PhD students, but can be interesting also for postdocs or junior/senior researchers.

#### Learning objectives

By the end of this course, participants will be able to identify key national and international research funding opportunities and select appropriate financing strategies for different career stages. They will also develop skills to effectively evaluate funding criteria and craft compelling grant proposals tailored to impress evaluators.

title: Communicating Science: Basic Rules and Useful Tools
description:
In the lecture, the lecturer introduces you to the concept of science communication as an integral part of any research. She discusses the formal aspects of science communication, as well as target groups and various formats. She will give you tips on starting to communicate your research right away to your peers, together with useful tools. She will also explain how to reach broader audiences outside your professional field. The lecturer will give you an overview of the institutional role in science communication and show a few examples of Masaryk University's successful science communicators. 

#### Target group

This training activity is intended primarily for PhD students, but can be interesting also for postdocs or junior/senior researchers.

#### Learning objectives

By the end of this course, participants will acquire foundational skills in science communication, including targeting specific audiences and using effective tools to share their research. They will also learn to design communication strategies that broaden their reach beyond academia, leveraging institutional resources and successful examples for inspiration.

#### Learning objectives

This course equips participants to navigate ethical issues in artificial intelligence, particularly generative AI, and its applications in fraud detection. Participants will understand emerging challenges in AI ethics and apply recommendations from leading academic integrity organizations to their research practices.

title: Research Evaluation & Publication Integrity
description:
During the lecture we will briefly introduce different forms of research evaluation, especially with regard to the current evaluation methodology in the Czech Republic and the impact of evaluation in the scientific environment and scientific publishing.
We will discuss in more detail bibliometrics as a supporting tool for science evaluation and other possibilities of its use, especially for the development of publication strategies. The aim of the lecture will be to present good practice in scientific publishing and working with bibliometric indicators.

#### Target group

This training activity is intended primarily for PhD students, but can be interesting also for postdocs or junior/senior researchers.

#### Learning objectives

After completion of this course, participants will gain knowledge of contemporary research evaluation methods, including bibliometric tools and their implications for publication strategies. They will also learn best practices for scientific publishing and ethical considerations in evaluating research impact.

title: The Fall of an Empire or the Rise of Europe? (Autum 2024)
description:
#### Learning objectives

In the traditional historiographical narrative, the arrival of the “barbarians” corresponds to the end of the greatest civilization of the antique Mediterranean: the Roman Empire. But was the situation so simple? Who were these “barbarians”? And did the Empire really collapse or was it rather transformed? The goal of this course is to focus on the artistic, visual, material, and performative cultures that coexisted in this extraordinary moment of history. To reach this objective, we will firstly focus on the prejudices constructed from the Renaissance to our days about what was commonly considered as the “Dark Ages”. Secondly, we will be investigating the role of medias in the transformations of visual history: from sculptures to “bidimensional” images, from roll to codex, from the illusive image to the iconic one. Third, we will analyze the role played by the meeting of cultures – constitutive for the investigated period – in the birth of the “Middle Ages”.

This course is taught by the Department of Art History at Masaryk University. 

At the end of the course participants will:
- be able to orientate himself in the visual and material cultures of the Late Antique to Early Medieval world;
- understand the tools and the importance of visual culture within social and historical phenomena;
- fall in love with art history!

title: Introduction to Media Studies 2024
description: This  course  intends  to  give  an  overall  view  of  the  theoretical  frameworks  to  media  studies.  The  lecture  is organized around three major didactic issues that follow the evolution and concepts of mass communication through  the  genre  of  media  to  its  reception.  The  first phase  of  the  course introduces  the  historical development  of  mass  communications,  its  important  concepts  and  models  from  the  perspective  of  media theory and social theory. The second unit introduces the audience to the social and formal issues of media content, focusing on media genres. Finally, we review the traditions and experiences of audience theory and audience research, as well as the characteristics of audience formation, with a particular focus on fan cultures. Learning  outcomes:  by  studying  this  module,  students  acquire  knowledge  about media  history,  media technology,  media  theories,  media  content and  consumption.  They  will  learn  about  the  multiplicity  of theories  and  approaches  to media in  the  framework  of  human  and  social  sciences.  They  acquire a  critical attitude  towards  media  culture  and  media  society  as  well  as  some  practical knowledge about  potential beneficial and harmful effects of media contents.\n

title: Conference - Introduction to research ethics and scientific integrity (French)
description:
The half-day study session has an introductory function, demonstrating the value to researchers of critical and problematic reflection on research ethics and scientific integrity. Its aim is to raise doctoral students' awareness by outlining the main issues and concepts.

Description
Morning programme:
- Introduction to research ethics and scientific integrity led by Mathieu Rouault, Grand Labo science journalist.
- Lecture on legal and moral ethics by Jean-Marcel PIRIOU, research engineer at the CNRM (Centre National de Recherches Météorologiques), CNRS / Météo-France.
He provides training in ‘ethics and scientific integrity’ for doctoral students at the Toulouse Doctoral School. In 2012, he published the book ‘Happiness here and now’, which looks at the link between ethics, law and morality, and other notions of general philosophy. The lecture will be followed by a 30-minute discussion.
Presentation
In the first part, he will give examples of ethical, societal or research problems (debates on animal experimentation, localisation and 5G, plagiarism in research, tensions over co-authorship or the anteriority of results, the societal role of whistleblowers, etc.). He will then document the links and differences between ethics, law and morality: definitions, examples. He will discuss their causal links, and how ethical reflection drives the development of laws and morals. It will look at ethics in history. And he will give examples of ethical dilemmas in research, which will be an opportunity to present a central method in ethical reflection: identifying the values at stake, then sorting them out, and stressing the importance of an open and consensual debate on them (ethics committees). He will use examples to illustrate the link between values and virtues. He will also review scientific truth and its link with the ethical approach. He will define scientific ethics and integrity, and give examples. The final session will focus on the link between ethics and self-confidence, and how the ethical approach is liberating.
- Round table: Ethics and scientific integrity officer in higher education establishments: role and missions
The issues of scientific ethics and integrity are becoming increasingly important in the conduct of research, as well as in the publication of research results and the promotion of research. This concern must therefore emerge right from the research training that constitutes doctoral studies. In addition to the major ethical principles that prohibit plagiarism and the publication of fraudulent results, ethical issues arise throughout the research process, in the day-to-day work of the researcher, with the collection and use of data. This varies from one scientific discipline to another, but they are all involved in one way or another: protection of individuals, protection of digital data, animal rights and environmental protection, etc. In addition to the vigilance that researchers must maintain in their practice, they may also need to obtain authorisations from bodies dedicated to these aspects, which will be discussed in the course of this half-day training session.

title: MOOC - Research integrity in scientific professions
description:
This Mooc is available in French and in English

Objectifs
- Adopt a critical approach
- Support the requirements of research integrity
- Inform about research integrity issues
- Alert you to the mechanisms that can lead to scientific misconducts
- Encourage you to develop a sense of responsibility and conduct yourself in a spirit of scientific integrity

Descriptif

Since the Singapore Declaration on Scientific Integrity in 2010, the international scientific community has been mobilizing to ensure that the methodological and ethical requirements of research are more clearly asserted, in a context where the race for novelty and the introduction of a reinforced competitive logic are multiplying the risks of drift. In addition, stricter regulations and the challenges of social responsibility mean that the fundamental principles of scientific integrity must be understood and embraced.
France's various research organizations have stepped up their initiatives, and their convergence led to the signing of the Charter of Ethics for Research Professions by France Universités (Association of Universities and Higher Education and Research Establishments) and the main organizations in January 2015. Following the report submitted by Prof. Pierre Corvol in 2016, "Bilan et propositions de mise en œuvre de la charte nationale d'intégrité scientifique", several decisions were taken, including :

- doctoral schools must ensure that doctoral students receive training in ethics and scientific integrity,
- establishments have appointed a scientific integrity referent,
- a French Office of Scientific Integrity (OFIS) was set up in 2017 within the Haut Conseil de l'évaluation de la recherche et de l'enseignement supérieur (Hcéres). 

This mobilization was reinforced at the end of 2021 by the publication of a legislative decree on compliance with scientific integrity requirements by public establishments and foundations contributing to the public research service. This text introduces into the law a definition of scientific integrity and the obligation for establishments to ensure the awareness and training of their staff and students in respecting the requirements of scientific integrity.

Committed to this issue since 2012 with the adoption of a charter, the University of Bordeaux has, in partnership with the CPU, COMETS-CNRS, INSERM and INRA, developed the training course on scientific integrity that we are offering you.

- Module 3: Preventing scientific misconduct

title: Gender and careers (French)
description:
Objectives

On average, women now have higher levels of education than men. However, they find it harder to get a job, are more likely to find themselves in precarious situations, are often paid less and have fewer opportunities for promotion, including in academia. For example, the salary of a male manager is five times higher than it was at the start of his career, while that of a female manager is only 2.7 times higher (INSEE 2010). This situation can be explained by a number of factors: the burden of domestic tasks and bringing up children, lower professional ambitions, male solidarity, less assertiveness, dedication to the company without sufficient recognition of the work done, etc.

The aims of this course are:

-  to help doctoral students identify the various factors that can limit their ability to advance and to give them the means to avoid having to put up with a situation,
- examine the impact of male domination at university and how it relates to other forms of discrimination,
- learn about policies to promote gender equality at university and their possible limitation

Course description
1.  Exposure of socio-historical obstacles (in particular the "glass ceiling" that women still encounter in their professional careers, including in academia, and the illusion of equality already there and its confusion with gender diversity),

2.    Legislation, legal instruments and resources to counter this situation.

3.    Interactions based on situations experienced by doctoral students.

title: INTERFACE: English Oral Proficiency and Intercultural Competence - Winter 2024/25
description:
#### Learning objectives
INTERFACE (INTERculural proFiciency and orAl Competence in English) is a model project of social online teaching and learning. Since 2020, it has brought together about 300  B.A. English and B.Ed. English students from the University of Potsdam and Beit Berl College (Israel) and provides these students with opportunities to experience virtual collaboration. The course instructors in Germany and Israel (originally from the USA, South Africa, and Great Britain) focus on improving students’ oral proficiency in English (accuracy, fluency, pronunciation), and participants have been able to attain a high proficiency in the main communicative language competences as outlined in the CEFR.
What is more, INTERFACE presents a form of didactic modeling, which is especially important for future educators. Student participants are encouraged to take an active role in this online project and thus have have a degree of autonomy (cf. UP Mission Statement for Teaching and Learning, “4. Target group-specific teaching”). They can select which digital tools work best for them, reflect on alternative assessment models (tasks and rubrics), and decide what constitutes authentic learning and a safe online learning environment. In doing so, they grow to understand the importance of collaboration and innovation. By working in English with speakers of Arabic, Hebrew, German, and other languages, the students question their ideas of the “Other” and grow to embrace diversity.  Furthermore, the project also prepares the students with skills for life and the workforce, such as flexibility and adaptability, social and cross-cultural skills, and accountability and responsibility (cf. UP Mission Statement for Teaching and Learning, “2. Career orientation and personal development”). 
**We welcome students in the EDUC alliance to participate in some of the sessions (for no ECTS points) or for all of the sessions (for an EDUC certificate stating 90 hours as workload, equivalent to 3 ECTS).** In both cases, students will be issued an EDUC certificate. **Passive participants will be removed from the Moodle course.**

title: EDUC Gap Semester - 2025/2026 Academic Year
description:
#### Learning objectives

The EDUC Gap Semester is a mobility programme that allows students to compose their own curriculum by choosing different fields of study at another partner university for one semester or a full academic year.
It is a unique opportunity for students to not only have a break from their current studies but also to explore the possibilities of alternative or complementary subjects, courses, and programmes that allow them to develop new knowledge and personalise their CV.

The EDUC Gap year allows students to open up to the wold by living and studying elsewhere in Europe, improving their language skills, and developing new soft skills. The EDUC alliance considers this mobility as a tool for developing a European sense of belonging and an asset for the social and professional success of students.
For details concerning courses attended by the student aforementioned, please refer to the official Transcript of Records.


#### Details of the learning scenario

This learning offer is a physical mobility of 1 semester in order to study other subjects than your initial training.
An interruption in your studies at your home university. Students are treated as exchange students at the receiving university, but this mobility, unlike an Erasmus+ mobility, does not count towards their degree (*except for MU students). It is an additional semester.

Students must select and attend a number of courses equivalent to 30 ECTS credits for one semester.


#### Scholarships
Students in this program receive an EDUC mobility scholarship from their home university to finance their mobility at the partner university. The amount of the scholarship varies depending on the home university and the destination.

title: MOOC - Ethics in Research (In French)
description:
Description

This MOOC was designed in 2018 within the University of Lyon's Research Ethics Platform.

Since May 2015, all PhD students have been required to train in scientific integrity and research ethics. The MOOC offered by the University of Lyon, focusing on research ethics, is aimed primarily at PhD students, but concerns all researchers and citizens who wish to reflect on the contemporary transformations and implications of research, and the new ethical issues they raise.

This MOOC complements the one on scientific integrity offered by the University of Bordeaux since November 2018.

Science is a core value of our democratic societies, which promote the desire for knowledge of the world and mankind. Nevertheless, new techno-scientific achievements and the acceleration of innovations sometimes frighten. In addition, the scale of the resources mobilized, a system of international competition and conflicts of interest between private and common good are also giving rise to a crisis of confidence.

How can we assume our responsibilities as citizens and researchers, on a personal, collective and institutional level?

The various themes addressed are: 

- Ethics and science today? 

- What is research ethics? 

- Why is ethics part of science?

- Science, technology, innovation and democracy

- The responsibility of researchers and institutions

- Conflicts of interest

- Conflicts of values

The intern will have the opportunity to contribute to industrial innovation projects aimed at supporting our customers in technological advancements for process and product improvement. Key areas of focus include structural optimization, thermostructural optimization, combustion, fluid dynamics, and the development of digital technologies for the biomedical industry.

The tasks:

- Analyze and interpret simulation results to suggest design improvements.

title: Comparative Study of Student Professions and Tutoring in Universities (France)
description:
**Duration of the internship**
3 to 6 months 
	
Option 1 - 3 to 6 months: this period would enable the trainee to collect data from the partner universities in the EDUC project, analyse the different practices in terms of tutoring and other student jobs, and write a detailed report with recommendations for your university. 

Option 2 - 6 months: this period would enable the trainee to carry out an in-depth analysis, with time for making contact and coordinating with several international universities, as well as making detailed comparisons. 

Option 3 - 3 months: this would be appropriate if the benchmark is more general, with a focus on the broad outlines of the practices observed.

**Hours per week**
37.5

**Preferred start date**
06.01.2025

**Preferred end date**
06.06.2025

**Further information about host organisation and relevant links**
UNIVERSITE DE RENNES

**Description of the tasks**
SUPTICE's Student Success Unit is looking for a trainee to carry out a comparative study of student jobs at university, with a particular focus on tutoring. Tutoring, a peer support system, plays a key role in student success by facilitating student integration and learning. We are particularly interested in the impact of tutoring and its various forms in universities, including distance tutoring arrangements, which enable students to be supported in a flexible way that is adapted to new ways of learning.  

This benchmark will include an international dimension by exploring the practices of the EDUC Alliance partner universities. 

Tasks to be carried out by the trainee:
Documentary research: Collect and analyse documentation on tutoring practices and other student professions in French and international universities.
Drawing up an inventory: Drawing up an inventory of the tutoring arrangements in place in the EDUC Alliance partner universities, including forms of distance tutoring.
Interviews and surveys: Conducting interviews with key players (students, tutors, teachers, educational managers) to gather qualitative data.
Comparative analysis: Comparing tutoring practices and student careers in different universities (formats, impact, organisation).
Drawing up a report: Presenting a full analysis of the results, with recommendations for improving the arrangements in place within our university.
Proposals for best practice: Identify levers for improvement and best practice based on an analysis of the various international experiences.
Presentation of results: Organise a presentation or summary report of the findings for the Student Success Unit team and the departments concerned.
The aim of this placement is to contribute to the development of the Student Success Unit's activities by providing an in-depth analysis of current practices and identifying ways of improving the existing systems within our university.

**Description of skills and competencies to be developed**
Ability to analyse and summarise: to process the data collected and compare university practices. 
Problem solving: to identify areas for improvement and propose solutions tailored to the needs identified. 
Information management skills: to organise information from different sources (universities, reports, surveys).
Organisational and planning skills: to complete the project on time, respecting the various stages of the benchmark. 
Ability to apply knowledge in practice: to transform theoretical analysis into practical recommendations and concrete actions for the Student Success Centre.

title: Create an online course in English! (France)
description:
**Duration of the internship**
2 months

**Hours per week**
35

**Preferred start date**
1 February 2025

**Preferred end date**
31 March 2025

**Further information about host organisation and relevant links**
UNIVERSITE DE RENNES. https://langues.univ-rennes.fr/en

**Description of the tasks**
Objective: To develop an online course for 3rd year medical students (those repeating the year), who have already passed their English course. The aim is to help them maintain and refine their English skills in preparation for the sixth-year critical reading of research articles exam.
1. Context and Goals
Third-year medical students repeating the year are no longer required to take English, despite the fact that the LCA exam in the sixth year necessitates ongoing practice. This internship will involve designing an online course that supports them in maintaining and strengthening their ability to critically engage with scientific English.
2. Structure of the Internship
•	Step 1:
o	Familiarization with the specific needs of medical students in relation to English and scientific research.
o	Getting familiar with what already exists on the Moodle platform for M3 students, to determine what extra content could be useful and get inspiration from already existing contents
o	Exploration of various tools and platforms suitable to integrate or for creating an online course (both synchronous and asynchronous formats).
o	Review of the key language skills required for understanding research English.
•	Step 2:
o	Development of the core content for the course, focusing on:
	Essential research vocabulary.
	Comparing the language used in popular science articles versus peer-reviewed scientific papers.
	How to break down and interpret complex titles and sentence structures.
	Methods for simplifying complex sentences to help improve comprehension.
o	Creation of interactive exercises, including video-based comprehension activities, where students watch researchers explain their work and answer related questions.
•	Step 3:
o	Development of engaging and interactive elements to make the sessions more dynamic and enjoyable (e.g., language games, group discussions).
o	Testing and refining the material with a small group of volunteer students.
o	Gathering feedback to then adjust and improve the course.
•	Step 4:
o	Finalization of the course content and preparation of self- assessment methods.
o	Internship report.
3. Expected Outcomes
•	An online course (either synchronous or asynchronous) designed to help students develop their critical reading skills in scientific English, tailored to their specific needs.
•	A set of interactive exercises, including video-based comprehension tasks and comparison of different types of scientific writing.
•	Engaging, simplified activities to help students grasp complex concepts.
•	Student feedback to help optimize the course.

**Description of skills and competencies to be developed**
•	Ability to analyse and synthesise 
•	Knowledge of a foreign language 
•	Ability to work autonomously 
•	Ability to generate new ideas (creativity)

title: A21 (low basic) Spanish Course
description:
#### Learning objectives

The objective of this course is to teach and provide the students with the necessary linguistic tools to be able to understand sentences and frequently used expressions related to areas of most immediate relevance (e.g. very basic personal and family information, shopping, local geography, employment);  to communicate in simple and routine tasks requiring a simple and direct exchange of information on familiar and routine matters; and describe, in simple terms, aspects of the past and the environment, as well as matters related to immediate needs.

**ORAL COMPREHENSION**
The student will be able to understand expressions and the most common vocabulary on topics of personal interest (e.g. very basic personal and family information, shopping, place of residence, employment), and the main idea of short, clear, simple messages and announcements.

**READING COMPREHENSION**
The student will be able to read very short, simple texts, find information such as advertisements, leaflets, menus and timetables, and understand short, simple personal letters.

**ORAL INTERACTION**
The student will be able to communicate in simple and routine tasks requiring a simple and direct exchange of information on familiar topics and activities; and maintain very brief social exchanges.

**ORAL EXPRESSION**
The student will be able to use a range of expressions and phrases to describe in simple terms their family and other people, their living conditions, their educational background and their present or last job.

**WRITTEN EXPRESSION**
The student will be able to write short, simple notes and messages relating to immediate needs, and write very simple personal letters, for example, to thank someone for something.

title: German A1
description:
#### Learning objectives

The course is suitable for learners who have never studied German before and who need a rather flexible setting which they can adjust to their own needs and prospects. 
The course comprises learning material related to typical areas of communication and basic needs in a German speaking community. Learners can explore the material along the steps Understanding (units with language input along with reflexion exercises, explanations and learning videos), Training (mainly vocab and grammar exercises), Testing (quizzes about language use) and Broadening the perspective (additional material from the Zessko as well as the internet). To ensure learners can manage without a tutor, all exercises come with either computer feedback or an answer key.
Upon successfully engaging in this course, learners: 

- can recognise concrete information (e.g., places and times) on familiar topics encountered in everyday life, provided it is delivered slowly and clearly.
- can understand some expressions when people are discussing them: personal and academic life, hobbies or surroundings, provided the delivery is slow and clear.
- can understand instructions addressed carefully and slowly to them and follow short, simple directions.
- can understand very short, simple texts a single phrase at a time, picking up familiar names, words and basic phrases.
- can guess the probable meaning of an unknown word/sign that is similar to one in the language they normally use.
- can produce simple, mainly isolated phrases about people, time and places.
- can ask and answer simple questions, initiate and respond to simple statements in areas of immediate need or on very familiar topics.
- can make an introduction and use basic greeting and leave-taking expressions.
- can ask for food and drink using basic expressions.
- can handle numbers, quantities, cost and time.


(Can-Do statements according to the CEFR)

title: Research Internship - AI4Space: Exploring Space Radiation Effects on Artificial Intelligence Hardware (France)
description:
**Duration of the internship**
3 to 6 months

**Hours per week**
24 to 35 hours

**Preferred start date**
No constraints 

**Preferred end date**
No constraints 

**Further information about host organisation and relevant links**
The International Affairs Department of the University of Rennes is made of an international team of 23 administrative staff. The Department is located in a modern and central building in the city of Rennes. Rennes is the capital city of the Brittany Region, in the west part of France. Just 1.5h by train from Paris and 1h from the seaside. Rennes is a vibrant city, with plenty of sports and cultural activities to do.

**Description of the tasks**

**Context**: Nowadays, Artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms can accurately perform many tasks, such as language processing, image and video classification, audio and radar processing, and instance segmentation [1 - 3]. Recently, large AI applications such as OpenAI GPT-4, Meta LLaMA3, and Mistral Mixture of Experts have captivated public interest with their high accuracy. Those applications demonstrated a high accuracy not only in one specific task but also performed well when processing multimodal data (e.g., a combination of text and images). Recent AI algorithms have also shown outstanding performance in space exploration, as they can process data locally in the satellites and send only useful information to Earth, avoiding unnecessary communication [4, 5]. 

Due to their resource-intensive nature, AI programs need dedicated hardware accelerators, such as graphics and tensor processing units, to be employed in any application, including space satellites. Unfortunately, the hardware resources necessary to execute current state-of-the-art AI software are highly vulnerable to radiation-induced errors present on space missions. The errors caused by ionizing particles in space can modify the hardware operations and propagate through the software, leading to failures in AI systems. 

This research aims to characterize the error rate of AI codes for space exploration. We plan to characterize the impact of faults on AI algorithms with fault injection and propose efficient fault tolerance methods.  

**Work proposal**: The student will conduct fault simulation on AI-based systems to simulate faults caused by space radiation. The experiments will be conducted on a Microchip PolarFire System on Chip development board, with various AI algorithms in operation. Following the simulations, we will assess how the faults affect the operating system and the AI algorithms. We can then propose algorithm-level fault tolerance to mitigate system failures resulting from radiation-induced faults. Depending on the project schedule and progress, we may be able to perform accelerated radiation experiments to evaluate the error rate and fault tolerance. 

Required skills: 
- Advanced Computer architecture knowledge 
- C/C++ programming 
- Python Programming 
- Advanced knowledge of embedded systems 
- Basics of AI and machine learning 
- Knowledge of hardware description languages is a plus. 

*References* :

[2] Chong Chen, et al., Compound fault diagnosis for industrial robots based on dual-transformer networks, Journal of Manufacturing Systems, 2023 
[3] Yuxin Fang, et al., EVA-02: A Visual Representation for Neon Genesis, CVPR 2023 
[4] Jakubik, J. et al., HLS Foundantion, https://github.com/nasa-impact/hls-foundation-os

title: Research Internship - Impact of bacterial motility on the accumulation of biosurfactants at air-water interfaces (France)
description:
**Duration of the internship**
5 to 6 months

**Hours per week**
35 hours

**Preferred start date**
03 February 2025 (flexible)

**Preferred end date**
07 July 2025 (flexible)

**Further information about host organisation and relevant links**
Webpage of senior supervisor: https://ipr.univ-rennes.fr/interlocuteurs/francois-peaudecerf

**Description of the tasks**

Evaporation from bare soils is a key hydrological process which returns a fifth of terrestrial precipitations directly to the atmosphere. This macroscopic phenomenon is governed at the microscale by capillary flows along water films between the top of the soil and the water at depth. The stability of these films is crucial to have an effective drying and it is highly sensitive to the physico-chemistry of the soil such as the surface tension at air-water interfaces or the contact angle of the aqueous phase with grains [1].  

In soil, bacteria abound, with ~ 1010 bacteria per gram of top soil. Many of them release surface active components – surfactants – in their surroundings which can strongly decrease the surface tension at air-water interfaces and change the contact angle [2]. To date, however, little is known about the potential impact of these bacteria on drying dynamics. How do surfactants accumulate at drying interfaces? Does bacterial behavior, in particular motility by swimming, modify this accumulation dynamics? What are the consequences on the interface behavior inside the soil pores? 

We started investigating these questions at the level of the single pore with the PhD project of Nathan Chapelle. We have already started developing an original experimental setup to follow the deformation of a single air-water interface which is put under evaporative forcing in the presence of surfactants, and validated our choice of model bacteria, B.subtilis. The goal of this internship is to get familiar with this setup and to shed light on the role of different bacteria phenotypes (in particular motile vs non-motile) on the repartition of bacteria and surfactants in the bulk and at this air-water interface. To do so, the intern will use microfluidic chips to mimic one pore of the soil, with an air-water interface present. Using optical microscopy techniques, he will track individual bacteria and characterize their behavior during evaporation from the interface. These results will be linked to changes in interface dynamics.  

The intern will be trained in and perform microfabrication by photolithography for microfluidics, microscopic imaging and image processing, particule tracking algorithms to follow individual bacteria as well as standard microbiological culture techniques. 

*References*: 

[1] D. Or and al., "Advances in Soil Evaporation Physics - A Review," Vadose Zone Journal, 12(4) 2013. 
[2] J Q Yang et al., "Evidence for biosurfactant-induced flow in corners and bacterial spreading in unsaturated porous media," PNAS, 118(38), 2021.

title: Luxury: Social Psychological Approaches for Professionals  (2024-2025)
description:
#### Learning objectives

The main objective of the course Luxury: social psychological approaches for professionals is to make students familiar with a social psychological perspective on the interactions in the world of luxury.
 
The course addresses the social psychological interactions and processes that underlie the world of luxury, as well as professional contexts in luxury businesses such as hotels, resorts, restaurants, the fashion world, make-up universes, etc. 

First, the course provides students with the social psychological keys to understand and contextualise the ways in which people think, feel, and behave in relation to luxury. 
 
Secondly, the course considers the contemporary stakes in the luxury world - for example, environmental concerns, as well as interactional stakes between luxury professionals and clients. 
 
Thirdly, the course equips students with the knowledge and tools to better understand the functioning of small groups, which are often created in luxury businesses: group affiliation and membership in work teams, leadership and its relation to group performance and group climate, norm formation, conformity, obedience, social influence, and social change, etc.
 
In addition, the course contributes to the development of students’ soft skills, such as active listening, leadership, conflict management, group work, cross-cultural interactional skills.

-**Economic and monetary union**

description:
#### Learning objectives

The expansion of Rome led to a particular form of social organisation: the Roman city. In the continuity of the Mediterranean city-states, this territorial modality of the civitas gave rise to several urban centres surrounded by their own territories, whose juxtaposition durably structured the Roman Empire. Organised around a community of citizens who governed it, the populus, the city enjoyed a certain autonomy under the same law. Buildings and monuments were the embodiment of this community and represented urbanitas, the urban way of life.

The objective of the course is to set out the modalities and the timeline of this expansion as well as the acceptance of the Roman Urban in the North West of the Roman Empire as any very first urbanisation in Europe.

title: Research Internship - Learning automata from their traces (France)
description:
**Duration of the internship**
6 months

**Hours per week**
37.5 hours

**Preferred start date**
February 2025

**Preferred end date**
July 2025

**Further information about host organisation and relevant links**
INRIA is a leading research institute in computer science, with 8 locations in France. The research center in Rennes is shared with the University of Rennes and other engineering schools, for a total of >700 persons covering most fields of CS. https://www.inria.fr/en/inria-centre-rennes-university  

**Description of the tasks**

Reconstructing a dynamic system from its trajectories is an old topic, addressed by several communities. This is called system identification in systems theory, equation discovery in physics, and automata learning in computer science. In CS, one may wish to recover an automaton from words of its language and possibly from counter-examples. Classical “exact” algorithms exist to do so, as the celebrated L-star by D. Angluin, but the latter relies on powerful oracles, i.e. on the possibility to make queries about some words. More recently, new approaches based on artificial neural networks architectures have reached impressive performances on this problem. Beyond performance, they are appealing by several aspects : they are passive methods, relying simply on data-bases of examples (no queries, no need for powerful oracles), they generalize extremely well and can be used as generators, and, focusing on Large Language Models LM, they manage to capture global text features that go beyond classical regularity - spelling, grammar, syntax - as for example style or even meaning. Last but not least, such approximate methods are poorly understood by computer scientists, and proving their reliability remains an issue.  
 
The objective of this internship is to explore the way various NN-based architectures manage to approximate a regular language, produced by some hidden automaton. The focus will be on the way the notion of discrete state emerges in these continuous space systems, and how reliable they are as approximators of automata. Several research directions are envisioned, that will be adapted to the skills and wishes of the candidate. We mention some of them below.  

- Exploring the approximation abilities of recurrent neural networks (RNN). RNNs are good ap- proximators of regular languages, but tend to build quasi discrete approximations resembling local automata. This property has to be further understood by examining how well RNN learn more complex languages, and by measuring the distance between the original language and the one ap- proximated by the RNN. This is both an experimental and a theoretical direction, as no algorithms yet exist to estimate such distances.  

- Exploring the robustness of the models learnt by RNN, to identify stable regions of their state space and unstable ones. The effect of extra data on such robustness also has to be characterized.  

- Replacing a true automaton by its RNN surrogate (used as a generative model for example) raises questions like its reliability. One would like to verify properties of runs produced by such soft automata, for example safety properties. Few algorithms yet exist for model checking such models, and they mostly focus on static feed-forward NN, not recurrent ones.  

- Exploring the properties of other architectures. While RNN have a vanishing memory, other structures like GRU or LSTM provide longer term memory. The approximation abilities of such models have to be better understood, in particular to characterize the family of languages they best suit.  

The ideal candidate should have a taste for formal methods and abilities for experimental work using standard machine learning libraries.  

See more details here https://people.rennes.inria.fr/Eric.Fabre/Master%202%20internship%202024.pdf

**Description of the tasks**

Control of remote interaction systems with force feedback is of paramount importance both in robotic teleoperation and virtual/augmented reality. Such systems are prone to stability
loss due to communication delays and specific features of the teleoperated environment.
Time-domain control approaches that leverage passivity theory have proven a flexible and successful tool in designing stabilizing control strategies that do not rely on the knowledge of a model of the environment. In such methods, however, the stability guarantee comes in general at the cost of a reduction of the level of transparency, i.e., of the degree of fidelity in force rendering at both the local and the remote side. Recent research has shown that some degrees of freedom in the design process can be exploited to improve the transparency of a given task under the stability constraint.

The objective of this research work is to design and evaluate novel time-domain stabilizing control strategies for multidimensional multi-user teleoperation systems aimed at the maximization of the level of transparency by means of online optimization.

The work will address the following points, tuned according on the expertise and interests
of the student:
-	Theoretical development and simulation of transparency-preserving control strategies based on convex optimization.
-	Software development for real-time implementation of the designed methods on real-world teleoperation systems.
-	Experimental evaluation and comparison of the performance of the developed control strategies. Design of case studies.

title: Research Internship - Control authority between a human and a robotic telemanipulator (France)
description:
**Duration of the internship**
5 to 6 months

**Hours per week**
35 hours

**Preferred start date**
No preference 

**Preferred end date**
No preference 

**Further information about host organisation and relevant links**
https://team.inria.fr/rainbow/ 

**Description of the tasks**
In the context of robotic teleoperation, control of the remote robot is often shared between the human user and an autonomous controller [Abbink, David A., 2018]. This sharing of control allows the human operator to benefit from the support of the autonomous system while retaining a certain degree of control over the robot. The autonomous controller can assist the human user by regulating the robot's movements to follow the operator's commands and
by performing autonomous actions to optimize the robot's trajectory and task execution more efficiently. Shared control is particularly useful in complex tasks that require high precision or are performed in challenging or dangerous environments. The resulting motion of the robot is a combination of the user's input and the action of the
autonomous controller, which is the result of one or more cost functions defined based on the task to be performed, such as maximizing the distance from workspace boundaries or minimizing the energy required by the robot. In these cases, haptic feedback can be highly beneficial in informing the human user about the actions of the autonomous controller [Abi- Farraj, Firas, et al., 2019; Selvaggio, Mario, et al., 2021]. Haptic feedback provides a deeper understanding of the actions taken by the autonomous controller, thereby enhancing the operator's trust in the decisions made by the autonomous system and enabling smoother collaboration between humans and machines. This synergy between the human operator and the autonomous controller improves the overall efficiency of robotic teleoperation and leads to more satisfactory outcomes in task accomplishment. Indeed, shared control enables to combine the precision of autonomous robotic systems with the cognitive capabilities of human operators. However, it may be challenging to define
how to best share the control of the robotic system in a way that is applicable to different users, tasks, and environments.

Our objective is to devise a shared-control approach, which adapts, relying also on haptic feedback, the allocation of control authority at run-time, according to the current confidence of the autonomous controller and performance of the user. This division is enforced through an input-mixing shared-control method, where the inputs from the automation and the human operator are weighted according to our authority distribution. At the current stage, the proposed technique is validated in a robotic cutting task: the users receive haptic feedback to inform them of the authority distribution in addition to the cutting constraints and the contact forces.

As extension of this work, we would like to analyse the effectiveness of the solution not only in terms of guidance but also for teaching more complicated tasks, e.g., how to move in a cluttered environment, as well as compare the proposed mixed-input approach with a haptic shared control method that changes the haptic feedback based on the measured robot and user confidence. The confidence metric introduced in this work can be then tested and validated in other robotic applications, such as drone navigation in cluttered environments.

The proposed workplan consists of
- Orientation and understanding of the problem: analysis and review of the relevant literature to
understand the control authority problem in the domain of robot shared-control strategies.
(Month 1).
- Preliminary hands-on session: familiarization with the experimental setup, the robotic
manipulator arm, the haptic interface and the existing software for the robotic cutting task.
- First preliminary experiments to collect new data to be analysed (M2).
- Solution enhancement and first experimental campaign: Implementation and validation of
possible improvements that could enhance the proposed shared-control solution for the robotic
cutting task. (M3).
- Expansion to other robotic applications: investigate how to scale the refined solution to other
applications or robot platform (e.g., drone navigation). Analysis and implementation of
possible modifications, required to tailor the proposed solution to the targeted application (M4).
- Preliminary validation on the new robotic application: validation, in a simulation environment,
of the improved authority allocation technique for the new robotic application, through an experimental campaign (user study).
- A validation in experimental scenario (e.g., in case of-drone navigation, with the drone platform available in the RAINBOW team) can be also
planned (M5).
- Final refinements, data collection and documentation: organize the collected results for
analysis. Document the implemented methodology, the provided solution and the deployment
in the new robotic application in a final technical report. Writing of a scientific paper(M6).

**Duration of the internship**
5 to 6 months

**Hours per week**
35 hours

**Preferred start date**
No preference 

**Preferred end date**
No preference 

**Further information about host organisation and relevant links**
https://team.inria.fr/rainbow/ 

**Description of the tasks**

Ultrasound mid-air haptic (UMH) interfaces [1] can focus sound waves to a chosen point in space, generating a high-pressure focal point. By moving this focal point fast enough, it is the possible to spread the energy along the trajectory, and therefore haptically stimulate the hand if it is close enough [2]. These interfaces can thus generate tactile stimuli in mid-air, without the need for any wearable equipment. 
 
In addition, tactile feedback is often used as a means to convey information (e.g. texture, force, ...) through touch. With a UMH interface, we can represent this information using the shape of the stimulus and it’s set of rendering parameters. It is therefore important to understand how well we can discriminate between several tactile stimuli, using different parameters. In terms of geometry, shapes can for instance vary in position, rotation and scale. While the discrimination in position [3] and rotation [3, 4] has been partially investigated, scale has received less interest. 
 
Among the many possibilities, circular patterns are often used because of their geometric and perceptual properties (e.g. rotation invariance, area maximisation for a given perimeter, ...) [5, 6]. It is therefore important to study our performance in discriminating tactile circles of different sizes, in order to optimise their rendering. 
 
This project consists of several steps: 
- Getting familiar with ultrasound mid-air haptic rendering. 
- Determinin which discrimination strategies can be used by participants to try to discriminate between two stimuli. This will allow us to design experiments where only geometric cues can be used. 
- Designing, implementing, and conducting user studies to measure human discrimination performance for circles of different sizes. 
- Analyzing the obtained data to verify our hypotheses and compute perceptual metrics. 
- Depending on the remaining time and the quality of the results, we may write and submit a scientific paper. 
 
[1] Rakkolainen, I., Freeman, E., Sand, A., Raisamo, R., & Brewster, S. (2021). A survey of mid-air ultrasound haptics and its applications. IEEE Transactions on Haptics, 14(1), 2-19. 
[2] Kappus, B., & Long, B. (2018). Spatiotemporal modulation for mid-air haptic feedback from an ultrasonic phased array. The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America, 143(3), 1836-1836. 
[3] Howard, T., Gallagher, G., Lécuyer, A., Pacchierotti, C., & Marchal, M. (2019, July). Investigating the recognition of local shapes using mid-air ultrasound haptics. In 2019 IEEE World Haptics Conference (WHC) (pp. 503-508). IEEE. 
[4] Pittera, D., Georgiou, O., & Frier, W. (2023). “I See Where This is Going”: A Psychophysical Study of Directional Mid-Air Haptics and Apparent Tactile Motion. IEEE Transactions on Haptics, 16(2), 322-333. 
[5] Frier, W., Ablart, D., Chilles, J., Long, B., Giordano, M., Obrist, M., & Subramanian, S. (2018). Using spatiotemporal modulation to draw tactile patterns in mid-air. Proceedings of the EuroHaptics Conference, 270-281. 
[6] Mulot, L., Howard, T., Pacchierotti, C., & Marchal, M. (2023). Improving the Perception of Mid-Air Tactile Shapes With Spatio-Temporally-Modulated Tactile Pointers. ACM Transactions on Applied Perception, 20(4), 1-16.

title: Research Internship - Identifying the metabolisms of Bathyarchaeia in continental wetlands based on stable isotope probing incubations (France)
description:
**Duration of the internship**
6 months

**Hours per week**
35 hours

**Preferred start date**
03 March 2025 

**Preferred end date**
30 August 2025 

**Further information about host organisation and relevant links**
- Personal webpage of S. Coffinet where the corresponding research project is described: https://ecobio.univ-rennes.fr/interlocuteurs/sarah-coffinet  
- General website of the host laboratory (UMR ECOBIO): https://ecobio.univ-rennes.fr/en  

**Description of the tasks**
Lignin, a complex biomolecule derived from vegetation, is a major component of organic matter in soils. Due to its highly aromatic and apolar structure, lignin is supposed to be hard to degrade by soil microbial communities and to accumulate in soils, notably in waterlogged wetland soils. Consequently, wetland soils are today considered as major carbon sinks and play a major role in the global carbon cycle and in climate change mitigation strategies. However, recent work on environmental archaeal phyla, such as Archaeoglobus fulgidus, Methermicoccus shengliensis and two stable enrichments of representatives of the class Bathyarchaeia, evidenced novel metabolic pathways to specifically degrade lignin in marine anoxic settings with comparable geochemical functioning as wetlands. This finding could challenge the assumed capacity of anoxic settings, such as wetlands, to sequester high amounts of organic carbon. The objective of this internship is to test the presence of these specific lignin degradation pathways in soils collected in a wetland of the Ploemeur-Guidel critical zone observatory (56, Brittany). Previous metagenomic analysis of these soils revealed high abundances of the recently-discovered archaeal taxon Ca. Bathyarchaeia and comprehensive bioinformatic analysis of genomes assembled from these metagenomes predicted the presence of the enzymes catalyzing lignin degradation. The work will be based on the stable isotope probing technique where 13C-enriched lignin-based substrates are provided to soil incubations. Incorporation of the labeled 13C within the biomass of Ca. Bathyarchaeia will be assessed by the analysis of the carbon isotopic composition of archaeal lipid biomarkers by gas-chromatography coupled to isotope ratio mass spectrometry (GC-IRMS).

title: Research Internship - Cluster-consensus control for swarms of robotic vehicles (France)
description:
**Duration of the internship**
6 months

**Hours per week**
35 hours

**Preferred start date**
As soon as possible 

**Further information about host organisation and relevant links**
https://erestrep.github.io/positions/ 

**Description of the tasks**
Description: The deployment of swarms of robotic vehicles has been shown to be effective for a wide range of applications based on cooperative tasks such as reconnaissance, surveillance, foraging or search and rescue. Most of the time, in such collaborative missions, the field of interest is relatively large with respect to the size of the multi-robot system. Therefore, the swarm must be divided into smaller groups (clusters) to move towards different areas and conduct different tasks simultaneously.
Motivations: Most of the current works addressing the problem of clustering for multi-agent systems are concerned with generic unconstrained agents, thus neglecting the constraints and specificity of networks of mobile robots in terms of limited sensing capabilities. Moreover, they only study the conditions for convergence of the agents to small groups, i.e. cluster consensus, rather than the autonomous formation of clusters. There are few works addressing the autonomous achievement of clusters in a network of mobile robots based on distributed and local interactions among the robots, none of which take also into account the sensing constraints inherent to these types of systems.
General Objectives: The goal of this Master Thesis is to design and validate theoretically (using Lyapunov methods, graph theory, etc.) novel control laws for the autonomous achievement of cluster consensus of a swarm of robotic vehicles subject to sensing constraints (limited range, limited field of view) based on local and distributed interaction laws among the robots. The work done during the internship will be validated in simulation and experimentally using a fleet of Crazyflie drones.

Envisaged Activities:
- Literature review of the related works and familiarize with the experimental setup in the team.
- Take over the existing works and work on the design and analysis of a control algorithm for autonomous cluster consensus of multi-robot systems
- Implement and validate in simulation the proposed algorithms.
- Validate experimentally the scenario on a fleet of Crazyflie drones.

title: Research Internship - Passivity-aware coordination of open multi-robot systems  (France)
description:
**Duration of the internship**
6 months

**Hours per week**
35 hours

**Preferred start date**
As soon as possible 

**Further information about host organisation and relevant links**
https://erestrep.github.io/positions/ 

**Description of the tasks**
Description and motivation: The deployment of fleets of robotic vehicles has been shown to be effective for a wide range of applications based on cooperative tasks such as reconnaissance, surveillance, load transportation and imaging. While a fixed number of cooperative robotic agents may be capable of performing “simple” short-term tasks such as, e.g., formation tracking, flocking, or area coverage, it may prove limiting in many practical scenarios. Indeed, as the field advances, applications of multi-robot systems are starting to shift from such relatively simple tasks, to more complex long-term and persistent missions that require the robots to be deployed for longer periods of time, usually surpassing the battery-charge duration of the devices, forcing individual robots to leave the network for recharging and (possibly) returning when fully charged. Moreover, as tasks get more complex and are designed for dynamic and, often, antagonistic environments, failure of individual robots due to malfunctioning or attacks cannot always be prevented. Equivalently, when addressing tasks in uncertain or unknown environments, in order to successfully accomplish the mission, new robots may be required to join the system dynamically as the task specification or the environment evolve. Usually during the development of a mission both the addition and removal of agents are bound to happen, oftentimes, simultaneously.
An Open Multi-Robot System (OMRS) is a system of multiple cooperative robots where agents can be added or removed. Recently, in our team we have started considering the coordination of OMRS in an passivity-aware framework [1] based on the concepts of impulsive switched systems, passivity, and energy-tanks, that allows the OMRS to handle the addition and removal of agents (or groups thereof) autonomously while preserving the passivity of the system.
General Objectives: The goal of this Master Thesis is to build upon the passivity-aware coordination framework for OMRS to design a complex and long-term mission on a fleet of quadrotor UAVs, e.g., a long-term surveillance and target-tracking mission, and implement it in simulation and experimentally.
Envisaged Activities:
- Literature review of the related works and familiarize with the experimental setup in the team.
- Design a long-term mission scenario based on the open Multi-agent system framework for a fleet of UAVs.
- Develop and implement in simulation an algorithm for the proposed mission.
- Setup the experimental scenario and validate the algorithms on a fleet of Crazyflie drones.
